column2: Diana's eyes never left the Sheik's face, she felt the old paralysing fear of him rushing over her, irresistibly drowning for the moment even the love she had for him.

column2: She had seen him in cruel, even savage moods, but nothing that had ever approached the look of horrible pleasure that was on his face now.

column2: But for the dying wretch expiating his crimes so hideously she felt no pity, he was beyond all sympathy.

column2: She had seen him murder wantonly, and she knew what her own fate would have been if Ahmed Ben Hassan had not come.

column2: One that came closer than the others made Diana turn her head and she saw what Ahmed Ben Hassan, absorbed in the fulfilment of his horrible task, had not even thought of--the three big negroes and a dozen Arabs who had stolen in silently from the inner room.

column2: I know you hate me, you have told me so already.
column3: I know you hate me, you have told me so already.

column2: Shall I make you love me?...
column3: Shall I make you love me?...

column2: Still disobedient?
column3: Still disobedient?

column2: When will you learn that I am master?...
column3: When will you learn that I am master?...

column2: I have not tired of you yet, you lovely little wild thing, _garcon manque...._ You say she is cowed; I say she is content--content to give me everything I ask of her....
column3: I have not tired of you yet, you lovely little wild thing, underscore garcon manque....underscore You say she is cowed; I say she is content-content to give me everything I ask of her....

column2: For four months she has fought me.
column3: For four months she has fought me.

column2: Why does it give me no pleasure to have broken her at last?
column3: Why does it give me no pleasure to have broken her at last?

column2: Why do I want her still?
column3: Why do I want her still?

column2: She is English and I have made her pay for my hatred of her cursed race.
column3: She is English and I have made her pay for my hatred of her cursed race.

column2: I have tortured her to keep my vow, and still I want her....
column3: I have tortured her to keep my vow, and still I want her....

column2: Diane, Diane, how beautiful you are!... What devil makes me hate Raoul after twenty years?
column3: Diane, Diane, how beautiful you are!... What devil makes me hate Raoul after twenty years?

column2: Last night she only spoke to him, and when he went I cursed her till I saw the terror in her eyes.
column3: Last night she only spoke to him, and when he went I cursed her till I saw the terror in her eyes.

column2: She fears me.
column3: She fears me.

column2: Why should I care if she loves him....
column3: Why should I care if she loves him....

column2: I knew she was not asleep when I went to her.
column3: I knew she was not asleep when I went to her.

column2: I felt her quivering beside me....
column3: I felt her quivering beside me....

column2: I wanted to kill Raoul when he would not come with me, but for that I would have gone back to her....
column3: I wanted to kill Raoul when he would not come with me, but for that I would have gone back to her....

column2: Allah! how long the day has been....
column3: Allah! how long the day has been....

column2: Has it been long to her?
column3: Has it been long to her?

column2: Will she smile or tremble when I come?...
column3: Will she smile or tremble when I come?...

column2: Where is Diane?...
column3: Where is Diane?...

column2: Diane, Diane, how could I know how much you meant to me?
column3: Diane, Diane, how could I know how much you meant to me?

column2: How could I know that I should love you?...
column3: How could I know that I should love you?...

column2: Diane, Diane, my sunshine.
column3: Diane, Diane, my sunshine.

column2: The tent is cold and dark without you....
column3: The tent is cold and dark without you....

column2: Ibraheim Omair! That devil and Diane!
column3: Ibraheim Omair! That devil and Diane!

column2: Oh, Allah!
column3: Oh, Allah!

column2: Grant me time to get to her....
column3: Grant me time to get to her....

column2: How the jackals are howling....
column3: How the jackals are howling....

column2: See, Raoul, there are the tents....
column3: See, Raoul, there are the tents....

column2: Diane, where are you?...
column3: Diane, where are you?...

column2: Grand Dieu!
column3: Grand Dieu!

column2: He has been torturing her!...
column3: He has been torturing her!...

column2: You knew that I would come, _ma bien aimee_, only a few moments while I kill him, then I can hold you in my arms.
column3: You knew that I would come, underscore ma bien aimee underscore, only a few moments while I kill him, then I can hold you in my arms.

column2: _Dieu!_ If you knew how much I loved you....
column3: underscore Dieu!underscore If you knew how much I loved you....

column2: Diane, Diane, it is all black.
column3: Diane, Diane, it is all black.

column2: I cannot see you, Diane, Diane...."
column3: I cannot see you, Diane, Diane...."

column2: And hour after hour with weary hopelessness the tired voice went on--"Diane, Diane...."
column3: And hour after hour with weary hopelessness the tired voice went on-"Diane, Diane...."

column2: CHAPTER IX
column3: CHAPTER nine

column2: It was evening when Diana opened drowsy and heavy eyes, a bitter taste in her mouth from the effects of the drug that Saint Hubert had given her.
column3: It was evening when Diana opened drowsy and heavy eyes, a bitter taste in her mouth from the effects of the drug that Saint Hubert had given her.

column2: Everything had been laid out in readiness for her waking with the little touches that were characteristic of Zilah's handiwork, but the Arab girl herself was not visible.
column3: Everything had been laid out in readiness for her waking with the little touches that were characteristic of Zilah's handiwork, but the Arab girl herself was not visible.

column2: The lamp was lighted, and Diana turned her head languidly, still half confused, to look at the clock beside her.
column3: The lamp was lighted, and Diana turned her head languidly, still half confused, to look at the clock beside her.

column2: The tiny chime sounded seven times, and with a rush of recollection she leaped up.
column3: The tiny chime sounded seven times, and with a rush of recollection she leaped up.

column2: More than twelve hours since she had knelt beside him after drinking the coffee that Raoul had given her.
column3: More than twelve hours since she had knelt beside him after drinking the coffee that Raoul had given her.

column2: She guessed what he had done and tried to be grateful, but the thought of what might have happened during the twelve hours she had lain like a log was horrible.
column3: She guessed what he had done and tried to be grateful, but the thought of what might have happened during the twelve hours she had lain like a log was horrible.

column2: She dressed with feverish haste and went into the outer room.
column3: She dressed with feverish haste and went into the outer room.

column2: It was filled with Arabs, many of whom she did not recognise, and she knew that they must belong to the reinforcements that Ahmed Ben Hassan had sent for.
column3: It was filled with Arabs, many of whom she did not recognise, and she knew that they must belong to the reinforcements that Ahmed Ben Hassan had sent for.

column2: Two, who seemed from their appearance to be petty chiefs, were talking in low tones to Saint Hubert, who looked worn and tired.
column3: Two, who seemed from their appearance to be petty chiefs, were talking in low tones to Saint Hubert, who looked worn and tired.

column2: The rest were grouped silently about the divan, looking at the still-unconscious Sheik.
column3: The rest were grouped silently about the divan, looking at the still unconscious Sheik.

column2: The restlessness and delirium of the morning had passed and been succeeded by a death-like stupor.
column3: The restlessness and delirium of the morning had passed and been succeeded by a death like stupor.

column2: Nearest to him stood Yusef, his usual swaggering self-assurance changed into an attitude of deepest dejection, and his eyes, that were fixed on Ahmed Ben Hassan's face, were like those of a whipped dog.
column3: Nearest to him stood Yusef, his usual swaggering self assurance changed into an attitude of deepest dejection, and his eyes, that were fixed on Ahmed Ben Hassan's face, were like those of a whipped dog.
